ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I have learnt a lot about theories, concepts, systems and practices about International Human Rights. Also, it has been a good opportunity for me to have a deeper understanding of this issue.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There are good presentations from both instructors and classmates and we can  exchange our ideas from different perspectives, which are really helpful for me to understand different situations and understandings about this issue. About the improvements, maybe we can have more videos and essays about cases rather than those about concepts which are more interesting and attractive.

This course is extremely challenging in terms of the volume of the required readings for each class - sometimes the content of these readings was not ever discussed. The classes themselves are very "dry" - there were almost no discussions; the majority of the live sessions only included lectures from the professor.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course as it is helpful for students to understand human rights issues and can make friends with friendly and excellent friends around the world.

narratives.question_text: The Canvas course site allowed me to identify and access required course materials easily.
